bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, October 29, 1940

div1.p: Kean discusses his health and the dinner at the University of Virginia honoring Moran. He speaks about Finlay's mental condition during his later years. He also describes the dinner given in Havana celebrating the confirmation by the Yellow Fever Board of the Finlay theory.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, October 29, 1940

opener.dateline:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Tuesday
Oct. 29, 1940

div1.p:
I have been a poor corres-
pondent lately as I have been
on a visit to my son in Rich-
mond and on my return last
Friday had, before I could
clean my disk, an attack of
paroxysmal auricular fihillatine
to which I am subject for now
5 or 6 years and which, Tho -
not very dangerous, leaves me
quite weak and good-for-nothing
for some days- My son Dr. Robert
H. Kean (who is not an M. D. but a
Ph. D. in Chemistry) drove me up to,
Charlottesville for the Moran dinner
2
we had perfect weather and were
home again by midnight, after
a very pleasant time. There were
26 present including your brother
and Mr. Clemons the librarian-
Moran had made Dean Jordan
who presided, promise not to call
on him for a speech. Dr. Jordan
gave a brief outline of the yellow
fever episode which I followed
by an informal talk filling in
the points which he did not
touch on- When I got to the
volunteering of Moran & Kissinger
I said that Moran had exacted a
promise that he would not be
called on for a speech, but if
he kept his seal (as I had done)
I was sure he would not object
to answering any questions made
by his hosts-
3.
So they started in to ask them and
he, after he got started, secured
really to enjoy it and talked
freely and at length until it was
time to bring the dinner to an
end-

Mrs Kean forwarded to me in Rich-
mond your two letters and I
sent you on the 24th a telegram
to your mother's address, suggest-
ing that you eliminate the statement
on page 3 that Dr. Finlay was “slightly
touched”. Such an intimation in a
public address would, I feel sure,
be bitterly resented by the Cuban
people and would undo all
our efforts to re-establish good feeling
between the Cuban doctors and the pro-
fession in this country- Also I
do not think it was true of him
4
at the time that Reed knew him-
and I first knew him- Some ten
years after, his mind began to fail
from senile dementia and he was
retired on his 75th birthday Dec. 3.
1908- with a handsome pension &
the title of Honorary President of the
National Board of Health & Charities-
I think we should be careful to
treat his memory with great respect.

Did you read in my address at
Belroi on the dedication of Reed's
birthplace the account of the dinner
given by the Medical men of Havana
to Dr. Finlay on Dec. 22, 1900- To cele-
brate the confirmation by the Reed
Board of the Finlay theory of the trans-
mission of yellow fever by the Stego-
myia mosquito? It is also told in my letter
Was there more to this letter??
5
to Moran of which I think Mr Clemons
gave you a photostat copy-
I have been much interested in
your quotations from Lazear's letters
to his wife and am delighted that
you are in touch with her and that
she has been willing to help you.

Your five box with the diary
and other papers came last Saturday
26th I suppose the extracts you have
photostated are all right- Can you not
eliminate the reference to Col. V. E. Wood
the chief Commissary who was afraid
to ride over with us to Capt. Page's
“on account of the danger to his family” and
my rather unkind remark to Gen. Lee that
the only danger was that he might fall
off his horse- Gen. Lee had a poor opinion
6.
of officer who could not ride, and
a still poorer one of those who were
afraid- He was'nt afraid of anything or
any body and so could not understand
people who were- In the list of those
in Marianao who had yellow fever the &
after the names of some means that they
were fatal cases- as Long fellow in his
fine poem Moriturti Salutamus refers to
as those against whose names
The fatal asterisk of death is set-
I read over yesterday the entries for
1901-2 in the next volume of my
diary- There is'nt much, as things
moved rapidly and I think
it would be easier to copy
out extracts than to send the
volume, which is a thick one
and has many posted-in snap
shots of my young children etc-
7
I will go over it again however
in the near future before decid
ing- I must congratulate you again
on your discovery & identification
of Building No.1- It is perfect
and will, I am sure satisfy
every & Keptie- It is surprising
that after 40 years a wooden shack
like this would have survived
the termites and decay of a tropical
climate- I think your plan of
buying it and giving it to the
Cubans is fine if it is well enough
preserved to justify preservation-
You did not know when you wrote
if Dr. Cooke would be present at
the dedication last Saturday. I hope
he was there and I am keen to
hear now he impressed you and
how you find Kissinger compares
8
with Moran- I have not seen him
since 1901 but I have the impression
that he has gone into the hero
business rather heavily- Dr Cooke
has never shown any disposition to
exploit his experience at all, nor has
Captain England-

This is a rather disconnected letter
I am afraid as I have had many
interruptions since I began it-
I hope however that you will count
it as an answer to your very interest-
ing ones and will be good enough
to send me a full account of the
celebration- It is wonderful how
many threads of information you
have brought together in your
arduous researce- With congratulations
and all good wishes I am.
